HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This module introduces students to the biological concepts of emerging infections and events that drive pandemics. The content combines infectious disease and immunology and highlights international issues and contributing factors, such as socioeconomics. Content will highlight global citizenship via the interconnected challenges of infections. The module comprises lectures, workshops and seminars as delivery methods and incorporates active-learning to ensure students can synthesise and evaluate relative merits, attributes, issues and applications of the topics. Students will participate in and receive research-connected teaching across topics that are topical. The module will provide feedback to students on their progress and allow for adjustment of their learning. Assessment will include group work synthesising a portfolio of potential epidemic and pandemic threats (Bacterium X/virus X) and evaluating outcomes from the workshops, plus an elevator-style, short presentation focused on a selected workshop issue that evaluates and develops an in-depth perspective of infection biology. Materials will be included on the VLE to assist and promote assimilation and appraisal of the module content and will increase digital fluency.
Educational Aims
To develop core skills in critically evaluating issues associated with emerging infectious disease and pandemics using written reports generated from appraising student-led discussion workshops and verbal communication, which are transferable and key for employability.

To enhance ability to appraise the host contribution and response to interventions together with factors that can be exploited for the development of both diagnostic and control strategies
Marketing Module Synopsis
This is a key module for students on the MSc Infection and Immunity Programme and might also be taken by other MSc, MBioSci and MRes students whose interests include infection and immunology. The module is topical in light of the pandemic and will address areas of research-connected infection biology teaching across areas of broad relevance to infectious disease, as well as to coronavirus. The module includes research connected lectures, workshops and structured discussions on selected texts as student-led topics. The content will focus on areas of infectious disease that support the programme and are relevant in that: (i) they are current/topical or (ii) they address fundamental questions of general importance. In addition, students will also be supported with key research and ideas in emerging infections and pandemics, showing how interconnected interconnected nature of health and disease through integrating aspects of biology and society. The module assessments are aimed at: 1) writing a report on a selected emerging pathogen that communicates the multifactorial considerations for researchers and society 2) presentation of a key factor that contributes to or affects disease emergence and the response by society or an agency. The factor focused on will be selected from workshops and student-led discussions
Outline Syllabus
Lectures:
Lectures will focus on key pathogens that cause epidemic/pandemics with perspectives that will be evaluated by students. Topics will change to keep topical and typically include pathogens from this list: From Rinderpest to Foot & Mouth; HIV-1: The history of a recent pandemic, what we have learned?“; Arboviruses: Zika Dengue and Chikungunya the big three; Corona viruses: why they can cause a pandemic any time?; Ebola: The deadly virus always waiting; Salmonella (typhoidal and non-typhoidal) outbreaks; Influenza: The ever-returning pandemic, when will be the big one?
There will be lectures that link to workshop content that adds extra context: Emerging infections, risks to peace and prosperity. Pandemic Emergences in Humans: A historic perspective; Emerging Infections from Animal to Human and Back.; Vector biology and the geographical progression of human pathogens; Environmental and pathogen drivers contributing to pandemics; Infections in the animal stock and the connectivity of the food supply chain; Socioeconomic Factors to pandemics and Socioeconomic consequences
Workshops will include 4 sessions that focus upon:
I: From the source of an outbreak to a pandemic in humans.
To understand the connectivity of species and what are the conjunctions or stochastic events that will lead to an infection to jump from one species to another resulting in the endangerment of public health and food supply.
II: The dangers to the food chain: a pandemic in animal stock.
To understand the importance of protecting the food supply from infectious agents. Debate and discuss the fragilities of the balances.
III: Infectious agents and the risk to safety: Biodefence
Present a case scenario: discuss and solve. Debate a future approach
IV: Preparedness to a new health threat
This workshop will be based on a case report from our last decade experiences. A debate will be followed on how to develop a preparedness plan to mitigate a near-future threat.
Seminars:
Student-led seminars using research papers (breaking research, advances, perspectives) to be discussed
Teaching and Learning Methods
Research-connected teaching supported from the current research interests of the University staff as experts in their field will feature as part of the Liverpool hallmarks of curriculum 2021. Research-connected lectures will provide emerging infectious disease content using past and current examples to provide the background and supportive context to structure the module and ensure students learn core elements. Digital fluency is practiced by using online platforms. Group and student-led discussion will be part of the workshops fostering critical thinking. The workshops will provide a platform for students to synthesise and discuss content in greater depth, explore greater breadth of issues and evaluate scenarios and alternative perspectives. Integration of knowledge and content will emerge from discussion of emerging infections and pandemics and the interconnected nature of society, human health and disease emergence. Attendances will be recorded.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two coursework assessments. The assessments are designed to be authentic to the research experience.
The first assessment is a written report on a selected emerging pathogen that communicates the multifactorial considerations for researchers and society This assessment is designed to measure skills in communication of the multiple factors and complexity of disease emergence in relation to infection biology. The reference list constitutes part of the maximum word length. This assessment will contribute to 60% of the module mark.

The second assessment will be a presentation that focuses on a key factor relating to disease emergence developed from the workshops and student-led discussions and relevant to infection topics in the module. The 5-minute presentation will be in the style of a short conference style elevator pitch with 3 minutes of questions from staff and students. This assessment will contribute to 40% of the module mark.

Reassessment will use the same format but the report topic and presentation subject will differ. Mark will be capped at 50%. This will take place in the normal reassessement window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Resit opportunity will be possible

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Notes
This is a new module for the MSc programme Infection & Immunity for 2021 start. The university has one of the largest groups of researchers working on infectious diseases in the UK and one of the few with an actively recruiting undergraduate microbiology degree.students seeking an MSc with a familiar title and one that is suitable for many funders.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 To critically evaluate the history of both emerging animal and human diseases with major societal impact and interrogate the inter-species associations of infectious diseases
 LO2 Demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the origins and causalities of emerging pandemics with the underlying biology
 LO3 To recognise and discuss the direct health consequences and societal impacts of a pandemic as well as the indirect effectors compromising the livestock and the foodchain as a whole.
 LO4 Demonstrate a systematic understanding of individual pathogens causing emerging pandemics with their specific characteristics defining their gravity of the disease.
 LO5 Critically evaluate the precautionary measures needed to curtail or to minimise the damaging effects from emergence of a new pandemic.
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Deal with complex issues both systematically and creatively, and communicate their conclusions clearly to audiences
 S2 Develop transferable skills; exercising initiative; independent-learning ability; digital fluency

The university has one of the largest groups of researchers working on infectious diseases in the UK and one of the few with an actively recruiting undergraduate microbiology degree.students seeking an MSc with a familiar title and one that is suitable for many funders.

 LocationPeriod 
 
Liverpool campus
Semester 1


Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 To critically evaluate the history of both emerging animal and human diseases with major societal impact and interrogate the inter-species associations of infectious diseases
 LO2 Demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the origins and causalities of emerging pandemics with the underlying biology
 LO3 To recognise and discuss the direct health consequences and societal impacts of a pandemic as well as the indirect effectors compromising the livestock and the foodchain as a whole.
 LO4 Demonstrate a systematic understanding of individual pathogens causing emerging pandemics with their specific characteristics defining their gravity of the disease.
 LO5 Critically evaluate the precautionary measures needed to curtail or to minimise the damaging effects from emergence of a new pandemic.

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Deal with complex issues both systematically and creatively, and communicate their conclusions clearly to audiences
 S2 Develop transferable skills; exercising initiative; independent-learning ability; digital fluency

Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This module introduces students to the biological concepts of emerging infections and events that drive pandemics. The content combines infectious disease and immunology and highlights international issues and contributing factors, such as socioeconomics. Content will highlight global citizenship via the interconnected challenges of infections. The module comprises lectures, workshops and seminars as delivery methods and incorporates active-learning to ensure students can synthesise and evaluate relative merits, attributes, issues and applications of the topics. Students will participate in and receive research-connected teaching across topics that are topical. The module will provide feedback to students on their progress and allow for adjustment of their learning. Assessment will include group work synthesising a portfolio of potential epidemic and pandemic threats (Bacterium X/virus X) and evaluating outcomes from the workshops, plus an elevator-style, short presentation focused on a selected workshop issue that evaluates and develops an in-depth perspective of infection biology. Materials will be included on the VLE to assist and promote assimilation and appraisal of the module content and will increase digital fluency.
Educational Aims
To develop core skills in critically evaluating issues associated with emerging infectious disease and pandemics using written reports generated from appraising student-led discussion workshops and verbal communication, which are transferable and key for employability.

To enhance ability to appraise the host contribution and response to interventions together with factors that can be exploited for the development of both diagnostic and control strategies
Marketing Module Synopsis
This is a key module for students on the MSc Infection and Immunity Programme and might also be taken by other MSc, MBioSci and MRes students whose interests include infection and immunology. The module is topical in light of the pandemic and will address areas of research-connected infection biology teaching across areas of broad relevance to infectious disease, as well as to coronavirus. The module includes research connected lectures, workshops and structured discussions on selected texts as student-led topics. The content will focus on areas of infectious disease that support the programme and are relevant in that: (i) they are current/topical or (ii) they address fundamental questions of general importance. In addition, students will also be supported with key research and ideas in emerging infections and pandemics, showing how interconnected interconnected nature of health and disease through integrating aspects of biology and society. The module assessments are aimed at: 1) writing a report on a selected emerging pathogen that communicates the multifactorial considerations for researchers and society 2) presentation of a key factor that contributes to or affects disease emergence and the response by society or an agency. The factor focused on will be selected from workshops and student-led discussions
Outline Syllabus
Lectures:
Lectures will focus on key pathogens that cause epidemic/pandemics with perspectives that will be evaluated by students. Topics will change to keep topical and typically include pathogens from this list: From Rinderpest to Foot & Mouth; HIV-1: The history of a recent pandemic, what we have learned?“; Arboviruses: Zika Dengue and Chikungunya the big three; Corona viruses: why they can cause a pandemic any time?; Ebola: The deadly virus always waiting; Salmonella (typhoidal and non-typhoidal) outbreaks; Influenza: The ever-returning pandemic, when will be the big one?
There will be lectures that link to workshop content that adds extra context: Emerging infections, risks to peace and prosperity. Pandemic Emergences in Humans: A historic perspective; Emerging Infections from Animal to Human and Back.; Vector biology and the geographical progression of human pathogens; Environmental and pathogen drivers contributing to pandemics; Infections in the animal stock and the connectivity of the food supply chain; Socioeconomic Factors to pandemics and Socioeconomic consequences
Workshops will include 4 sessions that focus upon:
I: From the source of an outbreak to a pandemic in humans.
To understand the connectivity of species and what are the conjunctions or stochastic events that will lead to an infection to jump from one species to another resulting in the endangerment of public health and food supply.
II: The dangers to the food chain: a pandemic in animal stock.
To understand the importance of protecting the food supply from infectious agents. Debate and discuss the fragilities of the balances.
III: Infectious agents and the risk to safety: Biodefence
Present a case scenario: discuss and solve. Debate a future approach
IV: Preparedness to a new health threat
This workshop will be based on a case report from our last decade experiences. A debate will be followed on how to develop a preparedness plan to mitigate a near-future threat.
Seminars:
Student-led seminars using research papers (breaking research, advances, perspectives) to be discussed
Teaching and Learning Methods
Research-connected teaching supported from the current research interests of the University staff as experts in their field will feature as part of the Liverpool hallmarks of curriculum 2021. Research-connected lectures will provide emerging infectious disease content using past and current examples to provide the background and supportive context to structure the module and ensure students learn core elements. Digital fluency is practiced by using online platforms. Group and student-led discussion will be part of the workshops fostering critical thinking. The workshops will provide a platform for students to synthesise and discuss content in greater depth, explore greater breadth of issues and evaluate scenarios and alternative perspectives. Integration of knowledge and content will emerge from discussion of emerging infections and pandemics and the interconnected nature of society, human health and disease emergence. Attendances will be recorded.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two coursework assessments. The assessments are designed to be authentic to the research experience.
The first assessment is a written report on a selected emerging pathogen that communicates the multifactorial considerations for researchers and society This assessment is designed to measure skills in communication of the multiple factors and complexity of disease emergence in relation to infection biology. The reference list constitutes part of the maximum word length. This assessment will contribute to 60% of the module mark.

The second assessment will be a presentation that focuses on a key factor relating to disease emergence developed from the workshops and student-led discussions and relevant to infection topics in the module. The 5-minute presentation will be in the style of a short conference style elevator pitch with 3 minutes of questions from staff and students. This assessment will contribute to 40% of the module mark.

Reassessment will use the same format but the report topic and presentation subject will differ. Mark will be capped at 50%. This will take place in the normal reassessement window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Resit opportunity will be possible

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
